intro: Mascagnia vacciniifolia var. hispidula, commonly known as the hairy mascagnia, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Apocynaceae family and is characterized by its woody stems and opposite, ovate leaves. The plant produces clusters of small, tubular, pink to red flowers that bloom in the summer. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, making it a hardy shrub suitable for xeriscaping. Its unique appearance and adaptability make it a valuable addition to native plant gardens.
